moduleInfo.moduleTitle: Basic Theory and Practices/03 Helpful Formats 101/Format Combinations

overview.quote: Formats are the cheese around the pill that can save a boring topic and ruin a good one.
overview.introText: Combining two formats creates a richer, more dynamic video that maximizes engagement while maintaining simplicity. The right combinations amplify each other, creating content that's greater than the sum of its parts.

keyTerms.definition: The practice of combining two content formats to create a more engaging experience while ensuring they complement rather than compete.
Combinations where each format provides something the other doesn't, resulting in enhanced viewer engagement.
An eye-catching element (like a green screen) that adds authenticity and tangibility to your content.
Creating content structured to keep viewers watching longer through strategic format use.

actionPlan: Map how they complement each other

mainContent.title: Storytime + Listicle Magic
mainContent.text: Combining storytelling with a listicle format gives you emotional pull and structured retention. Start with your hook, then quickly introduce numbered lessons to keep viewers engaged through multiple mini-hooks.

mainContent.title: Green Screen Storytelling
mainContent.text: Adding a green screen to your storytime creates visual intrigue and authenticity. The screenshot or image serves as 'proof' while the partial reveal technique keeps viewers watching for the full visual payoff.

summaryPoints: Adds visual interest to talking head

mainContent.title: Listicle + Green Screen
mainContent.text: This combination works brilliantly for visual topics. The listicle structure provides the retention hooks while the green screen delivers the visual payoff that makes your content feel authentic and impactful.

proTips.text: Reveal green screen content gradually throughout your video - don't give away the payoff too early, but don't delay it too long either.
When using story+listicle combo, announce your format early with 'Lesson 1 of 4' to set clear expectations.

finalWords.emphasis: walk before you run, imitate before you iterate
finalWords.description: Keep your combinations simple at first - two complementary formats is the sweet spot.
